docs.title: Fundamentals of AD and Neuroscience Research
docs.text: This portal is a student-friendly knowledge base for learning Alzheimer's Disease (AD) research, with clear math explanations and simple examples.

docs.title: How to use this site
docs.text:
• Start with AD Basics
  • Then review Math & Methods
  • Follow the MRI & Machine Learning workflow pages
  • Use Resources for datasets and a glossary

docs.text: If you want to add content, use Markdown and submit a pull request (or request edit access).

docs.title: Did You Know?
docs.text: Interesting facts about the brain, neuroscience, and Alzheimer's Disease research.

docs.title: About the Brain
docs.text:
• The human brain weighs approximately 3 pounds (1.4 kg) but uses about 20% of the body's energy.
  • The brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons.
  • Information in the brain can travel at speeds up to 268 miles per hour.

docs.title: About Memory
docs.text:
• The brain can store an estimated 2.5 petabytes of information (equivalent to about 3 million hours of TV shows).
  • Short-term memory can hold about 7 items for no more than 20-30 seconds.
  • Sleep plays a crucial role in consolidating memories.

docs.title: About Alzheimer's Disease
docs.text:
• An estimated 50 million people worldwide are living with dementia today.
  • In the U.S., of the 5.5 million people age 65 living with Alzheimer's disease, two-thirds are women.
  • Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for 60-80% of cases.
  • The disease was first described by Dr. Alois Alzheimer in 1906.
  • Brain changes associated with Alzheimer's may begin 20 years or more before symptoms appear.

docs.title: About Research
docs.text:
• The first FDA-approved treatment for Alzheimer's was released in 1993.
  • Modern brain imaging techniques can detect brain changes years before symptoms develop.
  • Exercise and a healthy diet may help reduce the risk of cognitive decline.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Key terms and definitions used in neuroscience and Alzheimer's Disease research.

docs.title: D
docs.text: Dementia A general term for loss of memory, language, problem-solving, and other thinking abilities that are severe enough to interfere with daily life. Dementia is not a specific disease but rather a syndrome caused by various diseases and conditions. Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for 60-80% of cases. In modern medical terminology, dementia is also referred to as Major Neurocognitive Disorder (MND) in the DSM-5.

docs.title: P
docs.text: Parkinson's Disease (PD) A progressive neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects movement. It occurs when nerve cells (neurons) in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, weaken, become damaged, and die. These neurons normally produce dopamine, a brain chemical essential for controlling movement. Symptoms include tremor, muscle stiffness, slowed movement (bradykinesia), and impaired balance and coordination. PD also causes non-motor symptoms such as cognitive changes, depression, sleep problems, and autonomic dysfunction.

docs.text: Test your knowledge about Alzheimer's Disease, neuroscience, and brain structure.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
The human brain is the body's control center, responsible for everything from basic life functions to complex thoughts and emotions. Understanding its structure is essential for studying neurological conditions like Alzheimer's Disease.

Figure: Overview of human brain anatomy (Image: Public Domain, Wikimedia Commons)

docs.title: Major Brain Regions
docs.text:
Figure 1: Major regions of the human brain (Image: Public Domain, Gray's Anatomy)

The brain consists of four major regions:

docs.title: Cerebrum
docs.text:
• Largest structure of the brain
  • Gives us conscious control of our actions
  • Divided into two hemispheres: left and right
  • Responsible for higher-level processes including language, memory, reasoning, thought, learning, decision-making, emotion, intelligence, and personality

docs.title: Diencephalon
docs.text:
• Mediates sensations and manages emotions
  • Commands whole internal systems
  • The thalamus forms most of the diencephalon and acts as a relay station for sensory information

docs.title: Cerebellum
docs.text:
• Adjusts body movements and speech coordination
  • Maintains balance, posture, and coordination
  • Controls fine motor skills

docs.title: Brainstem
docs.text:
• Relays signals from the spinal cord
  • Directs basic internal functions and reflexes
  • Consists of three structures: midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata

docs.title: The Cerebral Cortex and Lobes
docs.text:
Figure 2: The four lobes of the cerebral cortex (Image: CC BY 3.0, Blausen Medical)

The cerebral cortex is the outer layer of the cerebrum and is divided into four lobes, each with specialized functions:

docs.title: Frontal Lobe
docs.text:
• Largest lobe of the brain
  • Executive functions: emotional regulation, planning, reasoning, and problem-solving
  • Motor functions: coordination and planning of movements
  • Contains Broca's area for speech production
  • Involved in personality characteristics and decision-making
  • Recognition of smell

docs.title: Parietal Lobe
docs.text:
• Processes sensory information: touch, pressure, pain, temperature, vibration
  • Handles spatial processing and manipulation
  • Contains the somatosensory cortex which receives sensory input from the entire body
  • Involved in speech, reading, and proprioception (body position awareness)

docs.title: Temporal Lobe
docs.text:
• Language comprehension and speech formation
  • Auditory processing: contains the primary auditory cortex
  • Contains the hippocampus, critical for memory, learning, and emotions
  • Processes sound-to-visual image conversion
  • Involved in nonverbal interpretation

docs.title: Occipital Lobe
docs.text:
• Smallest lobe in the cerebral cortex
  • Primary role in visual processing and interpretation
  • Handles distance and depth perception, color determination
  • Responsible for object and face recognition
  • Contains the primary visual cortex

docs.title: Mean and variance
docs.text: Definitions and intuition.

docs.title: Mean
docs.text: \[ \mu = \frac{1}{n}\sum x_i \]

docs.title: Variance
docs.text: \[ \sigma^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum (x_i - \mu)^2 \]
